div1.head: Military Orders for James Carroll, July 25, 1901
div1.p:
HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, July 25, 1901.

1. The transfer by the President, July 2, 1901, of 2d Lieu-
tenant Rawson Warren from the 12th Cavalry to the Artillery
Corps, with rank from February 2, 1901, under the provisions
of section 9 of the act of Congress approved February 2, 1901,
is announced by the Secretary of War. Lieutenant Warren
is assigned to the 5th Company, Coast Artillery, and will pro-
ceed to join that company at Fort Screven, Georgia. The
travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

2. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Sergeant
Edward R. Saunders, 93d Company, Coast Artillery, Fort
Stevens, Oregon, will be discharged from the Army, by way
of favor, by the commanding officer of his station. This sol-
dier is not entitled to travel-pay.

3. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Leon A. White, Hospital Corps, Fort St. Philip, Louisiana,
will be discharged from the Army by the commanding officer
of his station, under paragraphs 156 and 158 of the Regulations
of 1901 (paragraphs 144 and 146, A. R., 1895).

4. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, 2d Class
Privates Frank P. Brittain and Lem P. Strong, ordnance de-
tachment, Columbia Arsenal, Columbia, Tennessee, will be
discharged from the Army by the commanding officer of their
station, by reason of their services being no longer required.
These soldiers are entitled to travel-pay.

5. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Irvin Reems, Hospital Corps, Fort McDowell, California, will
be sent to Fort Snelling, Minnesota, and report upon arrival
to the commanding officer of that post for duty.

6. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Recruit
John Fox, general service, Columbus Barracks, Ohio, having
enlisted under false pretences, will be discharged without
honor from the Army by the commanding officer of his sta-
tion. Under paragraph 1564 of the Regulations of 1901 (para-
graph 1386, A. R., 1895), this soldier is not entitled to pay or
allowances, and final statements, except for deposits during
his last enlistment, shall not be furnished him.

Captain Harry Taylor in addition to his present duties will
proceed to and take station at Boston, Massachusetts, and as-
sume permanent charge of the works for the defense of Boston
Harbor, Massachusetts. The Portsmouth, New Hampshire,
office will be discontinued and all of the records pertaining to
that district will be transferred to Boston, Massachusetts.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

16. By direction of the Secretary of War, Contract Surgeon
J. Samuel White, U. S. Army, is relieved from further duty
at the U. S. General Hospital, San Francisco, California, and
will proceed via Seattle, Washington, to Fort Gibbon, Alaska,
and report in person to the commanding officer of that post
for duty, vice Captain Samuel T. Weirick, assistant surgeon,
U. S. Volunteers, recently appointed, and by letter to the
commanding general, Department of Alaska. The travel en-
joined is necessary for the public service.

17. By direction of the Secretary of War, Captain Samuel
T. Weirick, assistant surgeon, U. S. Volunteers, is relieved
from further duty at Fort Gibbon, Alaska, and will proceed
to San Francisco, California, and report in person to the com-
manding general, Department of California, for transportation
to Manila, Philippine Islands, where upon arrival he will report
in person to the commanding general, Division of the Philip-
pines, for assignment to duty. The travel enjoined is neces-
sary for the public service.

18. By direction of the Secretary of War, Contract Surgeon
James Carroll, U. S. Army, will proceed from this city to
Havana, Cuba, not later than August 5, 1901, for the purpose
of continuing the investigation into the causation and preven-
tion of yellow fever, and upon the completion of this duty will
return to his proper station in this city not later than October
1, 1901. The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.
✓
BY COMMAND OF LIEUTENANT GENERAL MILES:
